Campo Charro s/n, 37007-Salamanca, Spain Received 28 March 1995; revised 11 September 1995; accepted 11 September 1995 Abstract Synergetic effects in the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein have been studied over catalysts containing several molybdate phases. Two types of catalysts have been analysed: (1) pure bismuth molybdates with Bi/Mo ratios of 2/2 and 2/3 [BiMo(2/2) and BiMo(2/3)] and cobalt molybdate [ CoMo( 1 / 1 ) ] ; and (2) multiphasic molybdates consisting of three or four molybdates prepared by: (a) coprecipitation of cobalt and bismuth salts and calcination at high temperatures, (b) mechanically mixing in dry conditions the separate molybdates and calcining at high temperatures and (c) dispersing the separate molybdates in n-pentane and calcining at high temperatures. Synergetic effects are observed in multiphasic BiMo ( 2 / 2) CoMo and BiMo (2 / 3) CoMo catalysts. For BiMo (2 / 2) CoMo catalysts the highest synergetic effects in the conversion, yield and selectivity are observed. For the catalysts before test no new phase is formed after calcination while after test X-ray measure- ments indicate a practically complete transformation of cr-Bi2M03012 into y-Bi2MoO6 and MoO2 and traces of MoO3 and Biz~Moj ~O3. Neither contamination between phases is observed. The synergetic effects are explained by the cooperation between separate T-BizMoO6, MoO3 and (c~ +/3)-CoMoO4 phases in contact. The cooperation between phases is more effective when MoO3 is present in a large proportion. Keywords." Multiphasic catalysts; BiMoCo; Oxidation (selective) 1. Introduction In a general way, the selective oxidation of olefins can be considered as a process consisting of several steps. Thus, a good catalyst for such a reaction is achieved by using a multicomponent catalyst, where usually many phases are present. This enhancement of the catalytic properties for a mixture of phases with respect to each component phase ('synergy') has been attributed to different effects: (a) a bifunc- tional behaviour, when one phase is necessary for one step of a reaction and the second phase for another step, (b) formation of a solid solution or a mixed phase, (c) covering of one phase by the other phase through formation of a monolayer or epitaxial layers, (d) contamination of the surface of one phase by elements coming from the other and (e) remote control mechanism. Catalysts used in industrial processes for olefin oxidation generally contain Bi and Mo, but also other elements such as Co, Fe, Ni, V, etc. Nevertheless, few studies have been published on the influence of the third or the fourth element upon the catalytic activity of bismuth molybdate phases. For example, Ueda et al. [ 1 ] found that the addition of vanadium in the scheelite structure of ce-BizMo30~2 leads to an increase in activity and in selectivity to acrolein. The increase in activity could be attributed to the mobility of lattice oxygen ion in the Bil x/3Vl-xMOxO4 structure. Some evidence of the improvement in catalytic activity and/or selectivity to acrolein on bismuth molybdate supported on iron-cobalt molybdate has been reported by Moro-Oka et al. [2,3]. These authors ascribed the improvement in the catalytic performance to the positive influence of iron in the cobalt molybdate used as support. The improvement of the activity and selectivity when mixtures of bismuth mol- ybdate and mixed iron and cobalt molybdate are used as catalysts in the oxidation of propene to acrolein [4-6], are assigned to both: the ability of the bismuth iron cobalt molybdate particles to exchange electrons and oxygen anions, and to the change in the morphology of the catalyst under the conditions of the catalytic reaction. One of the multiphasic systems in which important synergetic effects in the selective oxidation of propene to acrolein have been observed, is that corresponding to mixtures of bismuth molybdate phases. Different explanations of such effects have been proposed. Carson et al. [7,8] have shown that a catalyst composed of an equimolecular mixture of a-Bi2M03012 and y-Bi2MoO6 phases is more active and selective in the selective oxidation of propene than either of the pure phases by itself. The observed synergetic effects are explained by considering the appropriate addition of the useful properties of each phase. Batist [9] considered that the improvement of the catalytic properties of 3/_ BizMoO6 when adding small amounts of MoO3 is due to the partial coverage of the 'Bi202' top layers, laying on the T-BizMoO6, by MOO3. A similar effect of MoO3 on the catalytic properties of "y-BizMOO6 was also observed by Matsuura et al. [ 10], but they ascribed this effect to the formation of an active surface layer with a Bi/Mo ratio of 1:1. S.R.G. Carraz6n et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 135 (1996) 95-123 97 The synergetic effect in the selectivity to acrolein found by E1 Jamal et al. [ 11 ] in mixtures of a-Bi2M03012 and T-Bi2MoO6 was interpreted in terms of the elim- ination of bismuth oxide layers in excess on top of the surface of the T-phase, either by distillation in vacuo upon heating at 480, or by chemical reaction with MoO> This led to the formation of a pure T-phase (or a- and T-phases) of high catalytic performance for acrolein formation in propene oxidation. The synergetic effect between the a-Bi2M030~2 and T-Bi2MoO6 phases is attrib- uted to the remote control mechanism by Bing et al. [ 12]. They considered that oxygen species emitted by the T-phase can migrate onto the a-phase surface where it creates or regenerates the active sites for acrolein formation. Weng et al. [ 13,14] also reported improvement of the catalytic properties of 7- Bi2MoO6 in the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein when it was mixed with SnO2, WO3 and MoO3 (acceptor phases) or a-Sb204 (donor phase). In this case, the synergetic effects are explained by a creation of selective sites due to spill- over oxygen (remote control mechanism). Strong enhancements of activity and yield in propene oxidation to acrolein have been found by Legendre et al. [15] when testing, in near industrial conditions, model catalysts containing cobalt, iron and bismuth molybdates. Two different tentative explanations are proposed to account for the observed synergetic effects, depending on the number of molybdate phases present in the catalysts. The so- called 'coherent interface' [ 16], which involves enhancement of oxygen anion and electronic conduction between the two phases at the interface, is proposed for catalysts containing two molybdate phases. In the case of three molybdate phase catalysts, a remote control mechanism is presented as the most probable. Thus, presently we found different and no conclusive interpretations which can explain the synergetic effects between phases depicted by catalysts consisting of three or more molybdates. The aim of the present work is to give some light concerning these factors. The strategy followed in this work was to study the effects of varying the number and degree of interactions of molybdate phases by preparing multiphasic catalysts with different proportions of the component phases and obtained using different exper- imental conditions. Pure bismuth molybdates with Bi/Mo ratios of 2/2 and 2/3 and cobalt molybdate were prepared separately. Multiphasic catalysts consisting of three or four molybdates were prepared by coprecipitation of cobalt and bismuth salts or mechanically mixing the single molybdate phases in dry conditions or by dispersing them in n-pentane, in order to vary the interaction between the phases. Calcination of the catalysts at high temperatures was also performed in order (a) to facilitate the formation of a mixed oxide or a solid solution and (b) to study the mobility of the atoms at the surface. In particular, some multiphasic catalysts were prepared by dispersing the pure molybdate in n-pentane in order to avoid contam- ination between the phases. Catalysts were tested in the selective oxidation of isobutene to methacrolein. High conversion levels were used and these values were approximately constant 98 S.R.G, Carraz6n et al. /Applied Catalysi~ A: General 135 (1996) 95-123 for the multiphasic catalysts containing either BiMo(2/2) or BiMo(2/3). In these conditions, phase transformations were observed during the test either for the pure molybdates or for the multiphasic molybdate catalysts. The selective oxidation of propene [ 7-12] over bismuth molybdate catalysts at lower conversion level than that used in this work shows that pure catalysts do not undergo phase transformations during the test. It might be speculated that if a phase transformation occurred, it could not be detected because of its small extent. If it had been the case, an important information, coming from the solid state transformations, could not have been taken into account to explain the synergetic effects. So, in this work high level conversion is used in order to achieve phase transfor- mations, that are observed either for the pure molybdates or for the multiphasic catalysts for which synergetic effects are also detected. In this way, we can assume that the synergetic effects have to be related to the phase transformations in the multiphasic catalysts. Another objective of this work is to correlate the synergetic effects with the phase transformations observed in the multiphasic catalysts. In order to correlate the catalytic activity with the solid state characteristics of the catalysts, a detailed physicochemical characterisation was carried out on all the catalysts before and after the test. As phase transformation is an important factor to understand the catalytic results, a rigorous study of such transformations has been performed by X-ray diffraction measurements to detect phase modifications or formation of new compounds and by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to detect the surface transformations occurring at 15-20 monolayers depth from the external surface. XPS was also used to detect surface contamination. As acidic properties may play an important role in selective oxidation of olefins [ 17,18], a surface acidity study of the catalysts was carried out by FT-IR monitoring of pyridine adsorption. 2. Pyridine was dried over a molecular sieve and then degassed in situ following the freeze-pump-thaw technique prior to the adsorption runs. The method was as follows: the solid was compacted to a self-supported disc of 1 cm diameter, 10-20 mg and was calcined in air at 400 for 1 h in the same cell in which the spectra were later recorded, in order to eliminate adsorbed organic impurities. The sample was then outgassed at 400 for 2 h, at a residual pressure of ca. 10-3 Torr. The cell has CaF2 windows, transparent to infrared radiation in the 4000-1200 cm 1 range. In the first part of the discussion the results of physicochemical characterisation will be considered. In the second part, the possible mechanisms to account for the observed synergetic effects will be discussed. 4.1. Pure molybdate catalysts 4.1.1. Pure molybdate catalysts The high catalytic performances of both BiMo(X)/CP/480/6 (X= 2/2 and 2/3) catalysts, i.e., high isobutene conversions and methacrolein yields and very high methacrolein selectivities, can be explained by considering the phases devel- oped during the test. As has been shown in the literature, y-Bi2MoO6 [ 1,13,14] shows a moderate activity and selectivity in the oxidation of propene (isobutene) to acrolein (meth- acrolein). However, its activity and selectivity can be improved by adding an oxide phase as MOO3, SnO2 or WO3 [ 13,14]. In this way, the large activities developed by both, BiMo(2/2)/CP/480/6 and BiMo(2/3)/CP/480/6 catalysts can be explained through a cooperation effect between the y-BizMoO6 and MoO3 phases. This cooperation could be initiated by the migration of the highly mobile oxygen ions from the y-BizMoO6 phase [ 27,28 ] to the surface of MoO> this initiating not only the creation and/or regeneration of total oxidation catalytic centres (these accounting for the increase in the conver- sion) but also selective centres (these accounting for the increase in selectivity). On the other hand, the low 'COz degradation' for BiMo(X)/CP/480/6 (X= 2/2 or 2/3) is also related to the cooperation between T-BizMoO6 and MoO3 phases, this cooperation being particularly better for the BiMo(2/2)/CP/480/6 catalyst. This fact can be explained because the T-BizMoO6 phase is largely present in BiMo(2/2)/CP/480/6 catalyst (58%), from the beginning of the reaction. Thus, prevention of MoO3 reduction is more effective for this catalyst as it is revealed by its lower MoO2/T-Bi2MoO6 ratio. Concerning the CoMo( 1 / 1 )/CP/500/2 catalyst, conversion, yield and selectiv- ity are lower than for BiMo(X)/CP/480/6 (X=2/2 or 2/3) catalysts. On the other hand, the high 'CO2 degradation' observed in this catalyst confirmed that this catalyst has a very low selectivity. 4.3.2.
